Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
October 2011 
 
 
 
 
Asian Bonds Online Website Project, Phase IV
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A key lesson from the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis is that strong local currency (LCY) 
bond markets are important for maintaining a better balance within finance sectors and for 
building financial stability in the region. During the crisis, the currency risk exposure of the 
region’s companies whose liabilities were denominated in foreign currency could have been 
mitigated if there had been well-developed LCY bond markets and adequate bond market 
information flows. Since the crisis, the development of bond markets has become an important 
part  of  the  policy  reform  agenda  of  many  regional  governments,  prompting  a  number  of 
initiatives  and  concrete  actions  to  facilitate  bond  market  development  subregionally  and 
regionally: (i) the Asian Bond Fund and Asian Bond Fund 2, established by the Executives’ 
Meeting of East Asia–Pacific Central Banks; (ii) the regional bond market development initiative 
of the Asia–Pacific Economic Cooperation; and (iii) the Asian Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI) of 
the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)+3.1 The AsianBondsOnline (ABO) website 
was started under the ABMI in May 2004 with the support of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). 
 
2.  This technical assistance (TA) aims to continue ADB support for disseminating and 
improving the information flow for the region’s bond markets.2  It is a continuation of three 
previous TA projects designed and implemented to promote economic efficiency and enable 
markets through various information-dissemination activities and related knowledge products.3 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  East Asia’s LCY bonds have emerged as a distinct asset class that showed great 
resilience during the recent global financial turmoil in 2008–2009 and as a key funding source 
for  governments  and  domestic  companies  in  the  region.  Collective  regional  initiatives  and 
government’s national efforts have enabled bond markets to play a larger role in domestic 
financing in emerging East Asia.  
 
4.  In  2008,  ASEAN+3  launched  a  new  ABMI  road  map  to  develop  liquid  and  well-
functioning  bond  markets  and  effectively  channel  the  region’s  abundant  savings  to  meet 
increased investment needs. To make the new ABMI road map successful, it is essential to 
ensure that issuers and investors can access an information network with accurate data and in-
depth analysis.  
 
5.  Since the endorsement of the ABMI, LCY bond markets in emerging East Asia have 
come  a  long  way.  They  have  expanded  significantly  in  recent  years,  driven  by  growth  in 
government and corporate bond markets, with total outstanding bonds at well over $5 trillion at 
the end of 2010. LCY bonds attract strong interest from domestic and foreign investors alike, 
both seeking more data, information, and analysis toward making their portfolio choices. The

development of efficient and liquid bond markets in the region. ASEAN+3 comprises the 10 members of ASEAN 
(Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar,  the 
Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam), plus the People’s Republic of China, the Republic of Korea, and 
Japan. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 August 2011.

development of bond markets in Asia requires that the flow of information, data, and analysis to 
global and regional investors be improved.  
 
6.  Since  its  launch  in  May  2004,  the  ABO  website  has  progressed  from  being  an 
information site on LCY bond markets in the region to a one-stop clearinghouse providing data 
and analysis on LCY-denominated government and corporate bond markets in the region, as 
well as information on their respective economic and legal environments, to key stakeholders 
such as institutional and retail investors, issuers, brokers, underwriting houses, policy makers, 
market regulators, and academics. A revamped ABO website was launched in April 2009 to 
reflect the priorities laid out in the new ABMI road map.  
 
7.  In terms of content, the website includes (i) structural aspects of LCY bond markets in 
the region (e.g., market infrastructure,4 rules and regulations,5 market activities,6 and market 
data7), updates on ASEAN+3 ABMI activities, and a large number of progress indicators; (ii) 
research outputs (e.g., market analysis and policy research), news articles, and commentary on 
the bond markets of each country in the region, as well as a knowledge center comprising a 
bond glossary, data releases, and a how-to-buy guide for bonds and bond funds; (iii) Market 
Watch, which is updated twice daily and provides the major market-priced variables and year-to-
date and month-to-date performance figures for each country;8 (iv) Credit Risk Watch, which 
presents, by region and by market, relevant and timely market data on the current global 
financial turmoil and provides a comprehensive view of the growing credit risk and volatility 
issues that affect Asian financial markets; and (v) information on new issuance9 and Islamic 
finance.10 Asia Bond Monitor (ABM), a knowledge output that uses data and analysis from the 
ABO  website,  has  advanced  from  semiannual  to  quarterly  publication,  which  marks  the 
expansion of ABO analysis from the government sector into the corporate bond market. The 
content of ABM has been expanded to include a section on policy and regulatory developments, 
as well as individual market summaries for nine markets. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA is a continuing project and study expected to expand the provision of information, 
data, and analysis related to emerging Asian bond markets through the management of the 
ABO website. This promotes monetary and financial cooperation and regional integration by 
developing  robust  LCY  bond  markets  in  the  region.  The  TA  objective  is  to  contribute  to 
developing robust LCY bond markets in line with the objectives of the new road map of the 
ABMI.  The  TA  supports  the  expansion  and  creation  of  knowledge  products  by  expanding 
coverage  of  the  region’s  corporate  and  government  bond  markets.  It  aims  to  improve

expanded in 2009 and 2010 to include issuance volume and foreign holdings in LCY bonds, disaggregated data on

transparency by providing (i) timely and relevant data and information to investors and (ii) 
unbiased analysis of LCY bond markets to facilitate cross-border investment in and demand for 
LCY-denominated bonds. 
 
9.  Key stakeholders—institutional investors, issuers, policy makers, researchers, and other 
private sector participants—access the ABO website’s information, data, and analysis of various 
bond markets in Asia and download market indicators and the latest regional economic reports 
and related publications. The quarterly ABM, produced by ADB’s Office of Regional Economic 
Integration (OREI) and the ABO team, has emerged as a key analytical source for investors, 
policy makers, and researchers. The table presents download statistics for the ABO website and 
compares the first half of 2010 with the first half of 2011.

10.  The ABO website is a public good that benefits all stakeholders. It improves information 
flows  related  to  bond  markets,  which  helps  make  bond  markets  more  transparent,  liquid, 
efficient, credible, and deep. ASEAN+3 has identified it as the key information and data source 
for institutional investors on LCY bond markets in emerging East Asia. Reflecting consistently 
positive feedback and the contribution of the ABO website to developing regional bond markets, 
the TA will explore expanding the coverage of domestic debt markets outside of ASEAN+3.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The components of the TA will include the following: 
(i)  Managing and upgrading the website. The TA will manage and upgrade the 
design and presentation of the ABO website, continuing to improve its usability 
and usage. 
(ii)  Expanding website content. The TA plans to enrich content by expanding the 
database on corporate bonds to include maturity profiles and characteristics of 
the top 30–50 corporate issuers in each market and providing (a) more detailed 
data on investor holdings to support the bond investor survey; (b) more detailed 
data on derivative products, including futures, interest rates and currency swaps, 
and hedging tools, among others; (c) a data set on the offshore renminbi market 
in Hong Kong, China that will be comparable to the existing data set for Hong 
Kong dollar-denominated bonds; and (d) a market summary on Islamic finance 
that will expand the data presented and be comparable to information available 
on individual country bond markets. 
(iii)  Expanding  coverage.  The  aim  of  contributing  to  the  development  of  bond 
markets may extend to covering selected economies beyond ASEAN+3. Bond

4   
markets in other subregions may still fall short of their potential and may benefit 
from inclusion on the ABO website and improved investor access to market 
information. 
(iv)  Developing a new data section on  banking. This new section will include 
banking statistics and analysis of emerging Asian banking systems. It will be 
primarily a study of individual banking systems that contrasts and compares their 
ability to provide finance with that of the bond markets. 
(v)  Conducting the annual Asian local currency bond market investor survey 
in  2011  and  2012.  This  survey  will  provide  a  better  understanding  of 
intraregional bond investments and the different classes of investors holding LCY 
bonds, including the type and maturity profile of bonds held by different investors. 
The importance of this survey is indicated by ABO’s annual market liquidity 
surveys  having  identified  the  lack  of  investor  diversity  as  the  factor  most 
constraining liquidity. 
(vi)  Publishing Asia Bond Monitor and working papers. The TA will continue to 
produce the quarterly  ABM, as well as policy briefs and working papers on 
important  issues  facing  the  region’s  bond  markets.  The  ABO  is  involved  in 
preparing technical studies on special topics relating to financial markets (e.g., 
Asia’s  non-deliverable forward  markets  and  liquidity  in  emerging  Asian  bond 
markets).  
(vii)  Conducting other surveys. The annual ABO user survey and the annual Asian 
bond market liquidity survey will allow the ABO team to properly assess the 
website’s content and relevance. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-IV). It is estimated to cost the equivalent of $1.5 million. This amount will cover the 
remuneration  and  travel  expenses  of  international  and  national  consultants  and  resource 
persons, the expenses of organizing conferences and workshops, equipment and database 
purchases, report production, and miscellaneous expenses. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The OREI will implement the TA, in close 
consultation with ASEAN+3 ABMI officials, and supervise the work of TA consultants. The TA is 
expected to be completed in 18 months, from October 2011 to March 2013. 
 
14.  The  TA  will  require  50  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  225 
person-months of national, which will cost $1,150,000 including remuneration, travel, and per 
diem. Individual consultants and resource persons will be hired according to ADB's Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Hiring a team of consultants 
will provide more benefits to ADB than engaging a firm by allowing (i) faster mobilization of 
consultants, (ii) greater control by ADB staff in selecting and managing individual consultants; 
and (iii) greater flexibility in engaging experts specializing in a broad spectrum of finance-related 
topics. The project team leader and contract administration team will be drawn from OREI staff. 
One international consultant, a bond market specialist, will help OREI supervise and coordinate 
the  activities  of  each  expert  and  consolidate  individual  outputs.  The  other  international 
consultants will be one economics editor, who will review and edit the contents of the ABO 
website  and  related  publications;  bond market  economists,  who  will  evaluate  in  depth  the

5 
development of various bond markets; and financial market specialists, who will evaluate in 
depth financial markets. About eight resource persons, recruited for a total of 2 person-months, 
will be invited to participate in seminars as speakers and discussants. 
 
15.  The TA requires the following national consultants to operate and develop the ABO 
website: one project coordinator and researcher to coordinate outputs and conduct research 
with financial analysts; a senior analyst to provide in-depth analyses, draft working papers, and 
contribute  to  publications;  and  six  financial  market  analysts,  each  with  country-specific 
assignments, who will monitor and analyze capital markets and policy issues in participating 
countries and assist in supervising the ABO website’s operation. One  website administrator and 
two web specialists are needed for system and database development and maintenance. One 
national consultant will be engaged for graphics and design, and two other consultants for 
typesetting  and  publication  layout.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
16.  Disbursements under the TA will be in accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment (e.g., computer 
hardware and software) and statistical databases will be purchased in accordance with ADB's 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and,  where  applicable,  in 
coordination  with  ADB’s  Office  of  Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  Office  of 
Administrative  Services.  After  TA  completion,  procured  equipment  will  be  turned  over  or 
disposed of in compliance with para. 68 of Project Administration Instructions.11 The estimated 
cost of new equipment, computer software, and databases is $40,000. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asian Bonds Online Website Project, Phase IV, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Bond Market Specialist (international, 18 person-months) 
 
1.  The bond market specialist will have overall responsibility for developing and maintaining 
the Asian Bonds Online (ABO) website. Specific tasks include the following:  
(i)  Identify  detailed  information  content  for  each  of  the  five  broad  areas  of  the 
website—market infrastructure, legal and regulatory framework, market activities 
(including bond issuing and trading), market data, and key indicators of market 
movements—as well as on government policies and initiatives, as outlined in the 
project document. 
(ii)  Review  and  supervise  daily  information  market  analysis,  policy  research,  and 
market commentary contents. 
(iii)  Review and identify the presentation of updated market information in the market 
watch pages of the website. 
(iv)  Identify sources of information for each of the  Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN)+3 countries and other Asian Development Bank (ADB) member 
countries  as  required,  including  talking  to  key  participants  in  bond  markets. 
Establish an ABO project database as a reliable alternative to the data from each 
country’s national database or the Bank for International Settlements database. 
(v)  Extend  the  data  and  coverage  from  government  and  corporate  bonds  to 
securitization of all kinds and establish a resource within ADB’s Office of Regional 
Economic  Integration  (OREI)  for  improving  securitization  bond  markets  in  the 
region. 
(vi)  Supervise web designers and programmers as they design and program all pages 
of the ABO website, following basic requirements outlined in the project document 
and set out by ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology. 
(vii)  Identify the best way to make the ABO website more interactive for policy makers, 
regulators, investors, market participants, and other stakeholders in the region. 
Publicizing the website, including presentations to targeted or potential users, will 
be facilitated by in-country seminars and market presentations. 
(viii)  Prepare quarterly progress reports and a final report on the ABO website, including 
its technical specifications and operational procedures. 
(ix)  Prepare drafts of the quarterly Asian Bond Monitor (ABM) under the supervision of, 
and in consultation with, relevant OREI staff. 
 
2.  Bond Market Economists (international, 5 people, 8 person-months) 
 
2.  The consultants will evaluate in depth bond market developments and finance sector 
reforms for preparing ABM and produce various reports on areas that may include integration 
issues, public expenditure financing,  and private sector financing, among others, and their 
effects on bond markets. Specific tasks include the following: 
(i)  Use  a  comparative  framework  to  determine  how  economies  cope  with  the 
challenges  of  bond  market  development  and  finance  sector  reform  and  how 
priorities are determined for the further development of bond markets and finance 
sector reforms. 
(ii)  Analyze whether gaps in expertise and capacity-building efforts exist and if they 
need to be filled to ensure the progress of bond market development and finance 
sector reforms.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
3.  Financial Market Specialists (international, 3 people, 6 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultants will evaluate in depth specific financial market issues (e.g., liquidity and 
securitization). Specific tasks include the following:  
(i)  Prepare brief literature reviews and draft a manuscript on local currency bond 
markets. 
(ii)  Compile data on various measures of liquidity, including bid–ask spread, turnover 
ratio, bond yield volatility, and resiliency. 
(iii)  Conduct a comparative study on bond market liquidity in developing Asia and other 
selected emerging and developed markets. 
(iv)  Discuss  the  importance  of  how  developing  a  reliable  and  liquid  government 
benchmark yield curve can play a critical role in developing local currency bond 
markets that are liquid. 
 
4.  Economics Editor (international, 18 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will review and edit the contents of the ABO website and ABM to ensure 
coherence and readability, sound economic arguments, and the highest publication standards. 
Specific tasks include the following: 
(i)  Examine economic arguments to assess if they are logical and based on accepted 
economic theory and principles. 
(ii)  Rewrite, add, or delete information and help revise various pages or sections, if 
necessary, to tighten economic arguments, fill gaps in the discussions, and ensure 
the smooth flow of ideas. 
(iii)  Examine the tables, figures, and charts to ensure data consistency within pages 
and documents and suggest deletions and additions to ensure that they are useful. 
(iv)  Edit ABO website pages, ABM, and other documents related to the ABO project. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Project Coordinator and Researcher (national, 18 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant will manage and coordinate project outputs and conduct research with 
various financial analysts in the team. Specific tasks include the following:   
(i)  Manage the daily operations of the ABO website, including approving the daily 
upload of website content produced by the ABO team. 
(ii)  Help to implement the ABO work plan by ensuring that the performance plans of 
ABO team members are carried out.  
(iii)  Oversee enhancements, at both front-end and back-end interfaces, of the various 
sections of the ABO website, including the sections Market Watch, Bond Indicators, 
Credit Risk Monitor, Repo Market, and Islamic Finance. 
(iv)  Help to supervise technical work done by ABO team members. 
(v)  Support the team leader in preparing management reports related to the ABO.  
(vi)  Liaise with ADB departments and other stakeholders on ABO matters.  
(vii)  Provide data support such as information on sovereign and corporate bonds issued 
in ASEAN+3 countries, including market activities, legal and regulatory frameworks, 
market infrastructure, and government policies and initiatives.

(viii)  Regularly review the major sections of the ABO website, screen and consolidate 
information on the internet and from other sources, regularly update the website, 
and check data integrity for consistency with source databases. 
 
2.  Senior Analyst (national, 18 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant will analyze liquidity in emerging Asian local currency bond markets. 
Specific tasks include the following: 
(i)  Contribute to various sections of the ABO website, including the sections Market 
Watch, Bond Indicators, Credit Risk Monitor, Repo Market, and Islamic Finance. 
(ii)  Help coordinate technical work done by the ABO team. 
(iii)  Provide research support for preparing ABM.  
(iv)  Perform regression analysis on data and research requests from OREI 
management, including the collection of data and other relevant information from 
data vendors such as Bloomberg, Reuters 3000Xtra, DataStream, and CEIC 
Database. 
(v)  Regularly review and update the major sections of the ABO website, screen and 
consolidate information on the internet and from other sources, and oversee data 
integrity checks for consistency with source databases. 
 
  3.  Financial Market Analysts (national, 6 people, 108 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultants will help the team leader develop and operate the ABO website. They 
will  be  familiar  with  capital  markets  and  policy  issues  in  participating  countries  and  have 
extensive experience in analyzing financial data, strong communication skills, and proficiency in 
standard  computer  applications  and  software.  Each  analyst  will  have  country-specific 
assignments, which will include the 10 ASEAN member countries and the People’s Republic of 
China; Hong Kong, China; and the Republic of Korea. Specific tasks for each country include 
the following:   
(i)  Compile information on sovereign and corporate bonds issued in ASEAN countries; 
the People’s Republic of China; Hong Kong, China; the Republic of Korea; and 
other  ADB  member  countries,  including  market  activities,  legal  and  regulatory 
frameworks, market infrastructure, and government policies and initiatives.  
(ii)  Manage the collection and organization of all data on the region’s securitization 
markets,  supervise  data  integrity  checks,  and  ensure  consistency  with  source 
databases. 
(iii)  Take the lead in organizing the structure and output tools for the securitization 
research database to support policy analysts, who will be the database’s main 
clients.  
(iv)  Help write up key topics related to Asian bond markets.  
(v)  Help guide the ongoing redevelopment of the ABO website’s function and design. 
Maintain various sections of the website, primarily on the regional market and other 
country sections that may be assigned by ADB staff and the team leader.  
(vi)  Assist in supervising ABO team members as they carry out the daily operations of 
the website, in particular by reviewing, editing, and approving their work on website 
updates for relevance and accuracy.  
(vii)  Provide research support to staff.

12  Appendix 3 
4.  Web Administrator (national, 18 person-months) 
 
8.  The  consultant  will  assist  in  redesigning  the  ABO  website,  including  its  database 
structure. Specific tasks include the following:  
(i)  Conceptualize,  pilot,  and  implement  site  navigation  and  layout  improvements 
based on user feedback and conventional web usability principles and practices. 
(ii)  Administer and maintain the Asia Bond Indicators and Market Watch databases. 
(iii)  Administer and maintain the task-management system and content-management 
system databases. 
(iv)  Administer, monitor, and configure the Reuters Investor Service data and news 
feed services. 
(v)  Prepare weekly, monthly, and annual site statistics reports and help analyze the 
results in light of site developments and external events. 
(vi)  Administer resources used by the ABO team on the ABO server such as data 
repositories, programs, and security systems. 
 
5.  Web Developers (national, 2 people, 36 person-months) 
 
9.  The  consultants  will  assist  in  redesigning  the  ABO  website,  including  its  database 
structure. Specific tasks include the following:  
(i)  Maintain and redesign the existing database schema for improved performance, 
data  integrity,  and  maintenance;  analyze  and  document  the  impact  of  such 
migration to existing programs, processes, and users; and plan, implement, and 
test the steps in migrating to minimize disruption and data loss. 
(ii)  Conceptualize,  pilot,  and  implement  site  navigation  and  layout  improvements 
based on user feedback and conventional web usability principles and practices. 
(iii)  Create  automated  systems  and/or  improve  existing  ones  to  make  back-end 
operations (data loading, cleaning, and extracting) faster and more accurate. 
(iv)  Assist ADB staff and the ABO team leader in designing the securitization database 
and/or data warehouse for conceptualization and defining and gathering data. 
(v)  Maintain the ABO contact list and the feedback and information email accounts. 
Design,  develop,  and  operate  email  surveys  and  newsletter  transmission  and 
reception systems. 
(vi)  Create and continually update functional and technical documentation pertaining to 
the site and data architecture and processes. 
(vii)  Assist in maintaining the Asia Bond Indicators and Market Watch databases. 
(viii)  Assist  in  maintaining  the  task  management  system  and  content  management 
system databases. 
(ix)  Assist in monitoring and configuring the Reuters Investor Service data and news 
feed services. 
(x)  Diagnose and repair errors encountered in the website and back-end processes.   
(xi)  Perform other tasks related to the website as assigned by the ABO team leader. 
 
6.  Web Graphics Designer (national, 18 person-months) 
 
10.  The web and graphics expert is responsible for creating and designing web pages as 
required by the project. Webpage design includes information design, layout, color, typography, 
and HTML programming. The consultant must have expert knowledge of digital design software 
and languages: Adobe Photoshop and PageMaker, CorelDRAW, Adobe Flash, HTML, and 
JavaScript programming. Specific tasks include the following:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  Design  and  render  superior-quality  web  pages  and  oversee  and  preserve  the 
integrity of website design. 
(ii)  Design new web pages, icons, and thumbnails and suggest modifications to the 
design of existing web pages. 
(iii)  Provide advice and opinions on the information design, architecture, interactivity, 
and usability of the website. 
(iv)  Create and design project materials such as brochures, leaflets, banners, and book 
covers, conforming with the One ADB, One Look standards. 
(v)  Carry out other tasks related to web graphical design as assigned by ADB staff. 
 
7.  Typesetters (national, 2 people, 9 person-months) 
 
11.  Typesetters will be hired to typeset all study-related material to be published. They will 
ensure that the text, tables, and figures are properly included and publications are in an orderly 
and clear format. The typesetters will work in close coordination with the manuscript editor, ADB 
staff, and the Department of External Relations.  
 
C.  Resource Persons (about 8 resource persons, approximately 2 person-months total) 
 
12.  Resource persons, with backgrounds as policy makers and/or subject experts, will be 
engaged to review publications and working papers and as participants in related seminars, 
workshops, and conferences.
